entry.title: Stewart Park Bridge construction making progress, nearing late fall completion
entry.summary: Roseburg's Stewart Park Bridge has stood as a shortcut across the South Umpqua River for commercial and residential travelers since 1933. However, as the years have gone on, the bridge has become worn and aged, with its paint beginning to…

entry.title: Adapt Integrated Health Care receives multiple awards for healthcare quality
entry.summary: Each year, the U.S. Health Resources & Services Administration (HRSA) recognizes growth and improvement in health care providers through the awarding of Community Health Quality Recognition (CHQR) badges.

entry.title: North Douglas County Fair brings fun for all
entry.summary: DRAIN — The 103rd North Douglas County Fair will be held Friday and Saturday at the Drain Civic Center, 241 S. First Street in Drain.

entry.title: Final update issued in Scholfield Ridge Fire
entry.summary: REEDSPORT — Coos Forest Protective Association issued a final update on the Scholfield Ridge Fire at 8:30 p.m. Monday, stating the fire was still held at 50 acres and was 57% contained.

entry.title: Umpqua, Smith, North Fork Smith Rivers fishery is closed
entry.summary: OREGON — Fishing for Chinook salmon, both hatchery and wild, has closed on the Umpqua, Smith and North Fork Smith rivers because the quota of 500 wild fall Chinook has been reached.

entry.title: Above normal temperatures coming, near record highs possible
entry.summary: DOUGLAS COUNTY — Almost a week of above normal temperatures is coming to the Umpqua Valley, with the potential for near record highs starting later in the week.

entry.title: DOUGLAS COUNTY EMPLOYERS DROP 230 JOBS IN JULY
entry.summary: August 20, 2025 3:40 a.m. Douglas County’s seasonally adjusted payroll employment decreased by 230 jobs in July after an increase of 160 in June and 90 in May. An update from the Oregon State Employment Department said that in the not seasonally adjusted private-sector industries in July, there were relatively large gains of 80 in...

entry.title: SALMON BAG LIMIT HAS INCREASED IN COOS BASIN
entry.summary: August 20, 2025 3:20 a.m. The salmon bag limit has increased in the Coos Basin, effective Tuesday. An update from the Oregon Fish and Wildlife Department said it has gone from two to three fish in aggregate, one of which must be hatchery salmon. Anyone can harvest wild Chinook, hatchery Chinook, and hatchery coho. Wild...

entry.summary: Presented by Littlejohn Financial Services, David Littlejohn, Matt Dickson and attorney Derick Simmons have our weekly local financial program.

entry.title: Chinook salmon fishing ends in Umpqua, bag limit increased for Coos Basin
entry.summary: Fishing for fall Chinook salmon on the Umpqua, Smith, and North Fork Smith rivers is now closed after reaching the quota of 500 wild fall Chinook.

entry.title: DOWDY PLEADS GUILTY IN UCC BUS CRASH
entry.summary: August 19, 2025 3:20 p.m. The News Review is reporting that on Monday, 32-year-old Johnathan James Dowdy of Coso Bay, pleaded guilty to multiple crimes in his collision with the Umpqua Community College’s softball team’s bus near Myrtle Point on April 18th. That crash took the lives of 19-year-old Kiley Jones and head coach Jami...

entry.title: GOVERNOR KOTEK DECLARES DROUGHT EMERGENCY IN COOS AND WHEELER COUNTIES
entry.summary: August 19, 2025 3:10 p.m. On Tuesday, Oregon Governor Tina Kotek declared a drought in Coos and Wheeler counties through Executive Order 25-19 and directed state agencies to coordinate and prioritize assistance to the region. According to the U.S. Drought Monitor, Coos County has been experiencing moderate drought since June 17th. Wheeler County has been...

entry.title: Coos Bay Driver Pleads Guilty in UCC Softball Bus Crash
entry.summary: Jonathan Dowdy of Coos Bay pleaded guilty to multiple charges in the April crash that killed UCC coach Jami Strinz and player Kiley Jones and injured eight others. Several counts were dismissed in a plea deal. Sentencing in Coquille is set for Sept. 11.

entry.title: INSIDE DOUGLAS COUNTY 8.19.25
entry.summary: U.S. Senator Ron Wyden was in studio to cover a variety of issues, from vote by mail, to timber revenue not coming to Oregon counties, to Secure Rural Schools Legislation, wildfires, the proposed Oregon State Veterans Home and funding needed from the federal level to more forward and more.

entry.title: Winston Council Passes Marijuana Facility Ordinance, Tables RV Park Stay Limits
entry.summary: The Winston City Council tabled a proposal to limit RV park stays and advanced Ordinance 75-724, which includes zoning and animal code updates and would allow recreational marijuana facilities in the city. The measure proceeds to further review and public input.

entry.title: Community conversation about Diamond Lake Boulevard improvements
entry.summary: Riding a bike on Diamond Lake Boulevard is not an easy — or safe — task. Take it from Thomas Guevara, Oregon Department of Transportation’s senior transportation planner and project manager, who used to ride his bike there.

entry.title: UCC Begins Work on Welcome Center and Medical Careers Hub
entry.summary: Umpqua Community College has begun building a $21.5 million Welcome Center and Medical Careers Hub. Opening in early 2027, it will centralize student services and expand medical training, backed by an $8 million state match and support from local partners.

entry.title: UCC's $21.5M project aims to transform Douglas County healthcare
entry.summary: ROSEBURG, Ore. - Umpqua Community College (UCC) has begun construction on a new Welcome Center and Medical Careers Hub, which was kicked off on Friday with the demolition of the Del Blanchard Administration Building.

entry.summary: August 18, 2025 6:30 a.m. Roseburg received the most measurable rainfall on a day since May, on Saturday.
